prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

para.paratext: The statute creating the Panel and defining the power of the Panel to transfer actions is of limited value in determining whether transfer is appropriate in a particular case. The statute establishes three requirements for transfer, but does not identify what characteristics of multiple litigation should be sufficient to conclude that transfer is appropriate. The Panel has stated a number of factors that it considers and, in some cases, has stated how it weighs particular factors.

Although it is impossible to identify a “philosophy” or “attitude” of the Panel towards transfer, it is apparent that the Panel recognizes that transfer is a powerful tool of judicial administration. The Panel's decisions reflect a willingness to impose significant burdens on individual litigants and their counsel in order that the overall burden and expense of the litigation to all parties might be reduced.[1] As one scholar has observed, however, “[i]t is important to emphasize, however, that the Panel is no rubber stamp endorsing transfer whenever a litigant seeks its aid.”[2] The Panel has also displayed considerable willingness to defer to the transferee judges, including leaving to the transferee court questions concerning how much consolidation or coordination is appropriate in proceedings transferred by the Panel for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[3]

It is impossible to divide actual transfer decisions in the way they are analyzed in this and the following chapters. This chapter focuses on the issues relating to the decision: to transfer or not to transfer. Chapter 6 considers the Panel's choice of a transferee court, Chapter 7, the selection of an individual transferee judge. The Panel has discussed these questions separately in different opinions, and has considered them within single decisions. The Panel has probably never, however, made its decisions on any front in the absence of information concerning the other decisions before it. The availability or non-availability of a suitable transferee judge may have a significant impact on the Panel's decision on whether it should order transfer. This discussion may be couched in terms of whether transfer would advance the just and efficient handling of the litigation, but the judicial availability may be the most important underlying fact coloring the Panel's decision. It is thus important to consider the factors discussed throughout this book in trying to advance arguments particularly likely to be persuasive to the Panel. Reading Chapters 5, 6, and 7 together will also facilitate the reading of Panel decisions in a way likely to reveal the Panel's indications of the reasons for its decisions.

This chapter includes discussion of the threshold requirements for transfer under the statute as well as the more factual and particular factors considered by the Panel in deciding transfer questions. The types of actions in which transfer has in the past been ordered is also discussed, although this information is more useful in evaluating the likelihood of the Panel ordering transfer in a given case than in persuading the Panel that transfer should or should not be ordered.

Factors relating to transfer fall into three categories: those making transfer more likely, those that actually make transfer less likely, and those rejected by the Panel as not bearing on the transfer decision. These categories are discussed respectively in §§ 5.6, 5.7, and 5.8. To some degree these factors can he considered discretely in each category, for some factors make transfer likely if present, but do not affect the decision if not present. The presence of conflicting class action claims is such a factor. Others exist on some sort of continuum, militating toward or against transfer depending on their presence or absence. The number of actions falls in this category, with transfer being more likely if there are more actions and less likely if there are few.

It is apparent from reviewing the Panel's decisions across the full spectrum of types of cases that the Panel is making judgments about the overall benefits of coordinating cases. In recent years, the Panel seems more inclined to find that alternatives to transfer would provide a more effective solution than centralization before a single judge. This may be true for dockets of several cases, not just two or three.[4] The Panel has explained that it has observed that centraliztion “not a cure-all for every group of complicated cases.”[5] Even the agreement of all parties on transfer does done ensure that transfer will occur. In one case the Panel denied centralization, concluding: “Although all responding parties support centralization, the Panel has an institutional responsibility that goes beyond accommodating the particular wishes of the parties.”[6]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
